results.title: The Abba story: the winner takes it all [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Littlestar Services, Chris Hunt and Steve Cole
results.brief_description: Beginning with the 1999 British production “Mamma Mia”, this fascinating documentary flashes between past and present to effectively capture the band who were phenomenally successful for 25 years and continue to capture new audiences today. Agnetha, Benny, Bjorn and Anni-Frid talk candidly (to varying degrees) to the camera, the first time they have been united since the band split up. We follow their success in the 1974 Eurovision song contest with “Waterloo”, their quick breakthrough from the one hit wonder tag to chart success in the UK and America, how they perfected their unique sound and look, the musical careers of the four prior to forming together, their marriage and separation, and their respective lives today - all interspersed with concert and recording studio footage. Interviews are conducted with fans like Bono, Tim Rice, and Australian director Stephan Elliot who attempts to explain why the band have attained a cult following with the queer audience, a somethat dubious fan- Malcolm McLaren, as well as Lasse Haalstrom who directed the band in “Abba: the movie”, following their Australian concert with a movie camera.

results.title: The 400 million
results.creator_credit: Garrison Films, Joris Ivens and John Ferno
results.brief_description: Looks at the history of China and the beginning of modern life there in the 20th Century, by focusing on the war with Japan. Japanese troops had taken control of Manchuria in 1931 before a full scale war broke out in 1937 which eventually lead to the capture of Beijing and Shanghai. This remarkable documentary covers these events through historial and geographic explanations, including maps and voice overs by actors impersonating Japanese generals. Publicises the role that Chinese Communists played in fighting against the Japanese. Includes footage of Communist leaders such as Zhou Enlai, who became China’s premier after the communists gaioned power in 1949. Commentary by Fredric March, written by Dudley Nichols.

results.title: The 400 blows = Les Quatre cents coups
results.creator_credit: Films du Carrosse and Francois Truffaut
results.brief_description: Truffaut’s stunning first feature introduced his alter-ego Antoine Doinel. A chronicle of emotions and events the director experienced at first hand, the film is based, not on nostalgia, but on Truffaut’s painful memories of his childhood and adolescence. The camera is objective, the rhythms reflect the patterns and unpredictability of everyday life. However the apparently random series of episodes does have a cumulative effect encapsulated in the memorable final image. While a fierce critic of the state of French cinema in the fifties, Truffaut was not a revolutionary like Godard but sought to return in his first feature to what he saw as the best traditions of the French cinema represented by Vigo and Renoir (Rossellini’s Germany Year Zero and Hitchcock’s The Wrong Man were also important influences). The title refers to the French idiom, ‘to raise hell’. Cast includes: Jean-Pierre Leaud, Claire Maurier and Albert Remy.

results.title: The 39 steps (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Adapted from the novel of the same name by John Buchan. An innocent bystander suddenly finds himself thrust into a world of danger and intrigue. This fast-paced, often humorous, spy chase thriller pays homage to Buchan rather than being a close adaptation of his novel and was later remade by Hitchcock as North By North West. The purpose of the chase - the MacGuffin as Hitchcock called it - becomes increasingly irrelevant except as the means of holding a series of vignettes together. Credits include: photography by Bernard Knowles; music by Louis Levy. Cast includes: Robert Donat, Madeleine Carroll, Lucie Mannheim, Godfrey Tearle and Peggy Ashcroft.

results.title: The 2-D shapes game
results.creator_credit: Stephen Bosustow Productions and Stephen Bosustow
results.brief_description: A magic drawing board introduces children to the 5 basic 2-dimensional shapes (square, circle, triangle, rectangle and ellipse). The film establishes the characteristics of regular plane shapes and helps children to recognize and name them. Suitable for primary grades.

results.title: The 1956 Olympic story [Winter Olympics in Cortina, Italy]
results.creator_credit: Helms Athletic Foundation, Harry Leaman and Norman Mackay
results.brief_description: Documentary film on the Olympic Winter Games in Cortina in the Italian Alps, 1956. Sets the panoramic views of Cortina and the venues where the 1956 Winter games will be held whilst highlighting the previous 1952 Oslo Winter games with footage of specific events. Also includes footage of Melbourne in 1956 featuring the Melbourne Cricket Ground and St Kilda Town Hall and images of the 1952 Summer games in Helsinki. Narrated by Fred Hessler.

results.title: The 1954 Redex trial
results.creator_credit: Litchfield Productions, Roland Litchfield and Peter Whitchurch
results.brief_description: A record of the 1954 Redex around Australia reliability car trial. The 9,600 mile route commenced at Sydney and passed through every Australian capital city. Only 124 of the 248 starters finished the 18-day trial. The film captures the atmosphere and illustrates conditions experienced by drivers in the trial as they drove through the rain, extremes of heat and cold, choking dust, across roads which in many places were rarely used bush tracks full of hazards to both car and their weary, strained drivers, who, at the same time had to be careful of secret controls to check their speed. Concluding sequences show arrival, welcome and presentation of the winner.

results.title: The 1940's house. Volume 2: episodes 4-5
results.creator_credit: Channel Four Television, Simon Shaw and Caroline Ross Pirie
results.brief_description: Part 2 of the Hymer’s 8 week stay in the 1940’s house. “1944-1945: the beginning of the end”: the first lot of wartime treats from the U.S turns up on the Hymer’s doorstep and is favourably received. D Day arrives and the family is treated to a picnic at the Biggins Air Show. When VE Day is upon them there’s a dance to attend with 1940’s enthusiasts. Kirstie is sent to work on aircraft and the family prepare to leave Braemar Gardens. “2001: Homecoming”: On returning from the 1940’s house, Lyn, Michael, Kirstie and the boys discuss how their lives have changed individually and as a family. We are also privy to bloopers from the show - scenes in which the family contravened the regulations laid down to them during the 8 week period. The War Cabinet provides feedback on how serious/usual their breaches were and how they think the Hymer’s fared in general. Footage of the Hymer’s visiting a refuge shelter at Chiselhurst is also shown.
